text.headline: Lives of Renaissance Thinkers
text.text: The scholars, philosophers, and scientists who shaped the Renaissance—and wrote in Latin.

text.headline: Petrarch
text.text:
Father of Humanism. Rediscovered Cicero's letters and sparked the revival of classical learning.

Key works: Africa, Secretum, Letters

text.headline: Nicholas of Cusa
text.text:
Cardinal and philosopher. Proposed the Earth moves and the universe has no center—a century before Copernicus.

Key work: De docta ignorantia (On Learned Ignorance)

text.headline: Marsilio Ficino
text.text:
Translated Plato and the Hermetic Corpus into Latin, sparking the Renaissance. Founded the Florentine Academy.

Key works: Theologia Platonica, translations of Plato & Hermes

text.headline: Aldus Manutius
text.text:
Venetian printer who invented italic type and the pocket book. Published first printed editions of Aristotle, Plato, and many Greek classics.

Founded the Aldine Press

text.headline: Pico della Mirandola
text.text:
Prodigy who knew 22 languages. His 'Oration on the Dignity of Man' became the manifesto of Renaissance humanism.

Key works: Oration on the Dignity of Man, 900 Theses

text.headline: Desiderius Erasmus
text.text:
The 'Prince of Humanists.' Most famous scholar of his age, he corresponded with every major thinker in Europe.

Key works: In Praise of Folly, Adages, Greek New Testament

text.headline: Nicolaus Copernicus
text.text:
Placed the Sun at the center of the universe. His book launched the Scientific Revolution.

Key work: De revolutionibus orbium coelestium

text.headline: Thomas More
text.text:
Lord Chancellor of England, executed by Henry VIII. His 'Utopia' invented a genre and a word.

Key work: Utopia

text.headline: Martin Luther
text.text:
Sparked the Protestant Reformation. Translated the Bible into German but wrote theology in Latin.

Key works: 95 Theses, On the Bondage of the Will

text.headline: Cornelius Agrippa
text.text:
Occult philosopher whose 'Three Books of Occult Philosophy' systematized Renaissance magic.

Key works: De occulta philosophia, De vanitate scientiarum

text.headline: Paracelsus
text.text:
Revolutionary physician who rejected Galen. Founded toxicology and pioneered the use of chemicals in medicine.

Key works: Paragranum, De natura rerum

text.headline: Philipp Melanchthon
text.text:
Luther's right hand and 'Teacher of Germany.' Reformed education across Protestant Europe.

Key works: Loci Communes, Augsburg Confession

text.headline: Andreas Vesalius
text.text:
Father of modern anatomy. His illustrated 'Fabrica' corrected a thousand years of errors about the human body.

Key work: De humani corporis fabrica

text.headline: John Dee
text.text:
Mathematician, astrologer, advisor to Elizabeth I. Coined the term 'British Empire' and sought angelic conversations.

Key works: Monas Hieroglyphica, Mathematical Preface

text.headline: Giambattista della Porta
text.text:
Polymath who wrote on natural magic, optics, and cryptography. Founded one of the first scientific academies.

Key work: Magia Naturalis (156 editions!)

text.headline: Tycho Brahe
text.text:
Greatest observational astronomer before the telescope. His precise data enabled Kepler's laws.

Key work: Astronomiae instauratae mechanica

text.headline: Giordano Bruno
text.text:
Philosopher who proposed infinite worlds and a universe without center. Burned at the stake for heresy.

Key works: De l'infinito, De monade

media.caption: Bruno's statue in Campo de' Fiori

text.headline: Francis Bacon
text.text:
Prophet of the scientific method. Argued that knowledge should be built through systematic experiment.

Key works: Novum Organum, New Atlantis

text.headline: Galileo Galilei
text.text:
Turned the telescope to the heavens and saw moons orbiting Jupiter. Prosecuted by the Inquisition.

Key works: Sidereus Nuncius, Dialogo

text.headline: Johannes Kepler
text.text:
Discovered the laws of planetary motion. Bridged mysticism and modern science.

Key works: Astronomia Nova, Harmonices Mundi

text.headline: Robert Fludd
text.text:
Rosicrucian physician whose elaborate diagrams mapped the cosmos as a living organism.

Key work: Utriusque Cosmi Historia

text.headline: René Descartes
text.text:
'I think, therefore I am.' Founded modern philosophy and analytic geometry.

Key works: Meditationes, Principia Philosophiae

text.headline: Athanasius Kircher
text.text:
The 'last man who knew everything.' Wrote on everything from hieroglyphics to volcanoes to China.

Key works: Oedipus Aegyptiacus, Mundus Subterraneus

text.headline: Baruch Spinoza
text.text:
Lens-grinder who wrote philosophy so radical he was excommunicated. Equated God with Nature.

Key work: Ethica

text.headline: Isaac Newton
text.text:
Discovered gravity and calculus. His Principia unified terrestrial and celestial physics—in Latin.

Key work: Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica

text.headline: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
text.text:
Invented calculus independently of Newton. Dreamed of a universal language and calculating machines.

Key works: Theodicy, Monadology
